key_points: A claim suggesting the military raided Facebook and caused its outage by seizing servers circulated online after a six-hour outage affected Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp.
The outage occurred on Oct. 4, affecting users globally, with some services resuming around 5:40 p.m. ET the same day.
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg described the outage as the worst the company had seen in years.
The company debunked the raid theory, attributing the outage to human error during routine maintenance.
An engineer issued a command that unintentionally disrupted Facebook's global data center connections.
An audit tool that was supposed to prevent such an error failed to stop the erroneous command.
Restoration was delayed because the outage also removed Facebook from the Domain Name System servers, hindering internal investigation and resolution tools.
Engineers had to manually restart systems at data centers, a process lengthened by security measures.
Tom Parnell, a communications manager at Facebook, directly refuted the military raid claim, pointing to an explanation by Santosh Janardhan, Facebook's vice president of infrastructure.
The Department of Defense was reached for comment, but the claim has been rated as false based on facts.
spokespersons: Santosh Janardhan (Vice President of Infrastructure, Facebook)
